In compliance with the orders of Your Excellency, up the Guaíba River, I disembarked at ten o'clock at night at Ponta Rasa, and having already sent a cavalry detachment commanded by Lieutenant Isaías Antônio Alz. to Faxinal to escort the warship that had fallen into the hands of the rebels, to whose protection I was marching; but before that, even at night, I headed to Passo Fundo to engage a rebel force of over one hundred men commanded by Lieutenant-Colonel Tomás Pereira. However, he had already, out of fear, retreated from that position, and I learned that he had sent a detachment of over twenty men to Passo do Pesqueiro to protect the passage and transport of some wagons belonging to Antônio de Sousa Neto, commander-in-chief of the anarchist forces. Immediately, that very night, I proceeded to that pass, not only to protect the detachment I had sent to fetch the warship from Faxinal, but also to seize said wagons. Indeed, before reaching Passo do Pesqueiro, half a league away, and before dawn, I found the wagons with a guard of over twenty men, of which two were killed after greater resistance and 13 were captured, including ten soldiers, one faithful sergeant of said Neto, and 2 black men of his; two wagons of the equipment of Neto and the officers of his detachment, one covered cart, and another large transport wagon; six teams of tame oxen to drive them. I did all this with Battalion 2 commanded by Brigadier Filipe Neri, as the other part remained at Passo do Caí with its commander, Lieutenant-Colonel Fernandes; and not having yet received the repaired warship, despite having already sent it downriver for two and a half leagues by means of poles and towing, I ordered another detachment by land to meet it; on that occasion, I also asked Brigadier Filipe Neri to go by river in the steam boat with the force he commanded, which he promptly agreed to, and both forces encountered each other walking at a distance of almost half a league from Passo do Pesqueiro.

From there, I marched to Passo do Caí, at Contrato, to deliver the prisoners to Lieutenant-Colonel Fernandes, and proceeded with the wagons to Ponta Rasa, collecting along the way fifty cattle, which, along with the wagons, I had transported to the encampment at Picada, where they are now, all at the disposal of Your Excellency's orders.
